div.p: ANTONIO: Okay, I think we've got it now. Our level of biological risk—our trigger level—might suggest making that we make more conservative choices than others make, especially if I have a very low trigger level.
ANTONIO: So what's considered "low-risk" for some people might not apply to someone who has a strong family history of heart disease?

DR. COLLIVER: That's right. Or if, for example, a person trouble controlling their cholesterol with their diet, they may need different guidelines. Some people even need take medications to help prevent heart disease.
ANTONIO: So, what about people who already have heart disease?
DR. COLLIVER: Good question. They'd need to follow a different set of guidelines, as well. The basic recommendations are intended to reduce the risk in people that don't already have heart disease.
DR. COLLIVER: And again, if your biological risk is greater, then you would need to make even lower risk choices to reduce the likelihood of disease.

ANTONIO: So it's good to know how much biological risk you have, so you can do something about it. I mean, people who end up with heart disease didn't intentionally set out to pass their trigger level.
DR. COLLIVER: Right. They make high-risk choices, without knowing it, hoping or believing that heart disease won't happen to them.
ANTONIO: Or, maybe they don't think about their choices and the consequences at all.
